p: Recent literature data revealed that many of the phytotherapeutic molecules originate from plant-associated microbiota, although it is still highly unexplored area ( Köberl et al., 2013). In particular, the microbiota of medicinal plants is highly specific, depending on the unique bioactive secondary metabolites produced by medicinal plants ( Qi et al., 2012). Plants are acknowledged as an important source of LAB, although not systematically investigated. Recently, Köberl et al. (2019) identified the leaf surfaces and leaf endosphere of Matricaria chamomilla L. and Calendula officinalis L. as a source of LAB, with Enterococcaceae dominantly present in both plants, while Lactobacillaceae and Carnobacteriaceae were more abundant on M. chamomilla, and Leuconostocaceae and Streptococcaceae more abundant on C. officinalis. The specific aim of this study was the determination of A. ursinum-associated microbiota, as well as isolation and identification of LAB from A. ursinum with potential health-promoting effects.
